questions.text: Cataract in diabetic patients is because of the accumulation of sorbitol in the lens. The enzyme responsible for this is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aldol reductase A diabetic cataract occurs due to hyperglycemia-related activation of the sorbitol pathway . It may lead to Pre-senile cataract, an age-related cataract developing earlier in diabetic patients due to the accumulation of sorbitol within the lens, increased glycolytic carbamylation of crystallins, and greater oxidative stress.

Highyeild:

True diabetic cataract or snowflake cataract is bilateral, acute, cortical opacities seen in young patients with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus More commonly seen with type I DM

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Hexokinase Hexokinases phosphorylate glucose to produce glucose-6-phosphate , the first step in most glucose metabolism pathways. This gene encodes a ubiquitous form of hexokinase which localizes to the outer membrane of mitochondria. Mutations in this gene have been associated with hemolytic anemia due to hexokinase deficiency. Option: C. Glucokinase Glucokinase is an enzyme responsible for converting glucose into glucose-6 phosphate and plays a central role as a glucose sensor in regulating glucose homeostasis. Option: D. Phosphofructoisomerase Phosphofructokinase (PFK) is a tetrameric enzyme composed of three distinct subunits, muscle (M), liver (L), and platelet (P), which are variably expressed in different tissues, from Neuromuscular Disorders of Infancy, Childhood, and Adolescence.

Extraedge:

In milder cases, fluctuation of refractive error occurs about plasma glucose levels.

questions.text: A 70 yrs old patient with NIDDM underwent macular laser photocoagulation for mild non-proliferative retinopathy with macular edema eight weeks back and now shows features of vitreomacular traction. Management would be:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pars plana vitrectomy Diabetic retinopathy is the leading cause of blindness in patients between 25 and 74 yrs of age. Diabetic retinopathy is a long-term complication of diabetes due to microvascular ischemia and osmotic damage secondary to the chronic elevation in serum glucose. The molecular pathogenesis of these changes involves intraocular sorbitol accumulation , which consumes NADPH and leads to oxidative stress. This oxidative stress ultimately leads to damage to the retinal microvasculature . The release of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) by dying cells promotes the neovascularization of the retina and optic disc, which is characteristic of diabetic retinopathy.

Highyeild:

Classification- Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy presents without proliferation of new vessels. Mild- Any or all microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhage, exudates, cotton wool spots No IRMA or significant beading Moderate- Severe retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA Significant venous bleeding in 1 quadrant Cotton wool spots Severe 4-2-1 rule, one of Severe hemorrhage in all four quadrants Important venous beading in more than two quadrants Moderate IRMA in more than 1 quadrant Very severe Two or more of the 4-2-1 rule.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A. Biochemical mechanisms of cellular damage cause anatomic lesions like loss of pericles, being the earliest histological change/ sign of DR , causing impairment of the inner blood-retinal barrier and capillary basement membrane thickening resulting in hypoxia and retinal ischemic changes that activates various growth factors, which brings about neovascularization of retina, hallmark of DR Option: B . Proliferative diabetic retinopathy presents with the proliferation of new vessels Mild to moderate- neovascularization of the disc ( NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere ( NVE) Microaneurysm is the earliest sign of DR visible as tiny red dots On FFA hyperfluorescent due to leakage. Option: D . Retinal hemorrhage : Flame shapes arise from pre-capillary arterioles in nerve fibers layer, superficial Dot and blot arise from the venous end of capillaries in the outer plexiform layer, deep Exudates are lipid and lipoprotein deposits in the outer plexiform layer Visible as waxy yellow lesions.

Extraedge:

On FFA hypo fluorescent due to blockage Cotton wool spots : Collections of neuronal debris in the nerve fibers layer On FFA - hypo fluorescent due to blockage Venous changes - looping, beading, dilation, and tortuosity due to severe ischemia IRMA - arteriosus venous shunts bypassing the capillary bed NVD NVE

questions.text: SHIVRAJ, an Ola driver, comes to OPD with complaints of cloudy vision while driving at night for the past one month. On Examination, his eyes had the following features. What is the underlying cause of this condition
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diabetes mellitus It is associated with snowflake/snowstorm cataracts A diabetic cataract occurs due to hyperglycemia-related activation of the sorbitol pathway It may lead to pre senile cataract, which is age-related cataract developing earlier in diabetic patients due to accumulation of sorbitol within the lens, increased glycolytic carbamylation of crystallins, and greater oxidative stress.

Highyeild:

True diabetic cataract or snowflake cataract is bilateral, acute, cortical opacities seen in young patients with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus More commonly seen with type I DM

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: atopic dermatitis is associated with shield cataract Option: C. myotonic dystrophy is associated with Christmas tree cataracts Option: galactosemia is associated with oil drop cataracts

questions.text: A 61-year-old man, a known case of diabetes mellitus, presented with headache and eye pain. He also reports difficulty with driving at night. Visual field testing indicates peripheral vision loss. The ophthalmologist uses the following instrument during his examination of this patient. What does he measure by using the following instrument?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intraocular pressure The instrument shown is the Schiotz tonometer , which measures intraocular pressure (IOP). This patient's complaints of headache, eye pain, difficulty in adapting to darkness , and examination findings of peripheral vision loss with increased intraocular pressure are suggestive of glaucoma.

Highyeild:

Schiotz tonometer is a type of indentation tonometer . The principle behind its use is that the plunger will indent a soft eye more than a hard eye.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Angle of the anterior chamber Main Outcome Measures Anterior chamber depth was measured by optical pachymetry , slit lamp-mounted A-mode ultrasound, and handheld ultrasound . Gonioscopy was used to detect occludable angles, defined as one in which the trabecular meshwork was visible for less than 90° of angle circumference. Option: C. Corneal density Corneal endothelial cell density and pachymetry measured by contact and noncontact specular microscopy. Option D. Corneal thickness Ultrasound pachymetry remains the gold standard for measuring corneal thickness ; however, several non-contact methods are being used for this purpose by many clinicians. Orbscan II provides topographic information about the cornea and a corneal pachymetric map using the scanning slit method.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressive blurry vision in both eyes. His vision has not improved with the use of reading glasses. His blood pressure is 155/98 mm Hg. Physical examination shows his visual acuity to be 20/80 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. A photograph of the fundoscopic examination of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Diabetic retinopathy The fundoscopic image shows neovascularization of the optic disc and the retinal vessels. Diabetic retinopathy is a long-term complication of diabetes due to the microvascular ischemia and osmotic damage secondary to the chronic elevation in serum glucose. The molecular pathogenesis of these changes involves intraocular sorbitol accumulation, which consumes NADPH and leads to oxidative stress . This oxidative stress ultimately leads to damage to the retinal microvasculature. The release of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) by dying cells promotes the neovascularization of the retina and optic disc, which is characteristic of diabetic retinopathy.

Highyeild:

Classification- Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy presents without proliferation of new vessels. Mild- Any or all microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhage, exudates, cotton wool spots No IRMA or significant beading Moderate- Severe retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA Significant venous bleeding in 1 quadrant Cotton wool spots Severe 4-2-1 rule, one of Severe hemorrhage in all four quadrants Important venous beading in more than two quadrants Moderate IRMA in more than 1 quadrant Very severe Two or more of the 4-2-1 rule.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A . Idiopathic intracranial hypertension manifests with blurred optic disc margins (papilledema) and small hemorrhages on fundoscopy. Patients most often report significant headaches in addition to visual symptoms. Neovascularization of the retina, which is seen on this patient's fundoscopy, would not be expected in idiopathic intracranial hypertension. Option: B . A central retinal artery occlusion leads to sudden, unilateral vision loss, not chronic, bilateral blurred vision, which is reported here. Typical fundoscopic exam findings include a pale retina and a so-called " cherry red spot" in the fovea. Neovascularization and tortuous vessels, seen on this patient's fundoscopic image, would not be expected in a central retinal artery occlusion. Option: C . Dry macular degeneration is characterized by yellow deposits (drusen) on fundoscopy. Neovascularization, seen on this patient's fundoscopic image, would not be expected in dry macular degeneration.

Extraedge:

On FFA hypo fluorescent due to blockage Cotton wool spots : Collections of neuronal debris in the nerve fibers layer On FFA - hypo fluorescent due to blockage Venous changes - looping, beading, dilation, and tortuosity due to severe ischemia IRMA - arteriosus venous shunts bypassing the capillary bed NVD NVE

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important laser mechanism in diabetic macular edema?

options.label: B
options.text: Cut short the blood supply from the hypoxic area

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tickle RPE cells While there is currently no treatment for DMI, there are different treatments for patients with macular edema, including the photocoagulation treatment with focal or grid laser, which remains the gold standard of treatment for DME. The effect of laser photocoagulation on the retina for diabetic retinopathy is still unknown, although different explanations have been put forward.

Highyeild:

The first is the occlusion of microaneurysms. In focal laser treatment in cases of focal macular edema, direct microaneurysm photocoagulation around the macular area is thought to reduce the leakage from the MA with a consequent decrease in macular edema.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Makes the retina anoxic Laser surgery is the most common type of ROP surgery and uses a beam of light to create scar tissue on the peripheral retina. Using the laser, the ophthalmologist aims beams of light at the peripheral retina and burns, then scars, the area where abnormal blood vessels have not yet reached. Option: B. Cut short the blood supply from the hypoxic area. This is not the correct statement. Option: D. Stop neovascularization - this is not employed in the given case.

questions.text: The following statements are features of severe non-proliferative/Preproliferative Diabetic Retinopathy. Which of the following is NOT TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: Ischemic changes on background Diabetic Retinopathy produce it

options.label: B
options.text: The fundus is likely to show more than 8 to 10 cotton wool spots

options.label: C
options.text: Pre-proliferative retinopathy indicates progression toward proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy

options.label: D
options.text: Panretinal photocoagulation is the usual management guideline followed

questions.correct_answer: D. Panretinal photocoagulation is the usual management guideline followed
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Panretinal photocoagulation is the usual management guideline followed Frequent reviewing with Fluorescent Angiography is the usual line of management, and pan-retinal photocoagulation is done only if follow-up is not possible. Photocoagulation is also done with the first sign of new vessels in the retina. Diabetic retinopathy is a long-term complication of diabetes due to microvascular ischemia and osmotic damage secondary to the chronic elevation in serum glucose. The molecular pathogenesis of these changes involves intraocular sorbitol accumulation, which consumes NADPH and leads to oxidative stress . This oxidative stress ultimately leads to damage to the retinal microvasculature. The release of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) by dying cells promotes the neovascularization of the retina and optic disc, which is characteristic of diabetic retinopathy

Highyeild:

Classification- Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy presents without proliferation of new vessels. Mild- Any or all microaneurysms, retinal hemorrhage, exudates, cotton wool spots No IRMA or significant beading Moderate- Severe retinal hemorrhages in 1-3 quadrants or mild IRMA Significant venous bleeding in 1 quadrant Cotton wool spots Severe 4-2-1 rule, one of Severe hemorrhage in all four quadrants Important venous beading in more than two quadrants Moderate IRMA in more than 1 quadrant Very severe Two or more of the 4-2-1 rule.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Ischaemic changes over background diabetic retinopathy produce a pre proliferative diabetic retinopathy Option: B. The fundus shows IRMA/shunt vessels , and there is evidence of ischaemia, like more than 8–10 areas of cotton-wool spots Option: C.Venous Dilatation and other irregularities and arteriolar attenuation are also present. The above-mentioned changes indicate progression toward the proliferative diabetic retinopathy .

Extraedge:

On FFA hypo fluorescent due to blockage Cotton wool spots : Collections of neuronal debris in the nerve fibers layer On FFA - hypo fluorescent due to blockage Venous changes - looping, beading, dilation, and tortuosity due to severe ischemia IRMA - arteriosus venous shunts bypassing the capillary bed NVD NVE
